t: Job 10
Job Continues: A Plea to God
“I*pn loathe my life; I*ln will give free utterance to my complaint; I*ld will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ln will say to God, Do not condemn me; let*ld me know why you contend against me.
Does*ln it seem good to you to oppress, to*ld despise the work of your hands and*ld favor the designs of the wicked?
Have*ln you eyes of flesh? Do*ld you see as man sees?
Are*ln your days as the days of man, or*ld your years as a man’s years,
that*ln you seek out my iniquity and*ld search for my sin,
although*ln you know that I am not guilty, and*ld there is none to deliver out of your hand?
Your*ln hands fashioned and made me, and*ld now you have destroyed me altogether.
Remember*ln that you have made me like clay; and*ld will you return me to the dust?
Did*ln you not pour me out like milk and*ld curdle me like cheese?
You*ln clothed me with skin and flesh, and*ld knit me together with bones and sinews.
You*ln have granted me life and steadfast love, and*ld your care has preserved my spirit.
Yet*ln these things you hid in your heart; I*ld know that this was your purpose.
If*ln I sin, you watch me and*ld do not acquit me of my iniquity.
If*ln I am guilty, woe to me! If*ld I am in the right, I cannot lift up my head, for*ln I am filled with disgrace and*ld look on my affliction.
And*ln were my head lifted up, you would hunt me like a lion and*ld again work wonders against me.
You*ln renew your witnesses against me and*ld increase your vexation toward me; you*ld bring fresh troops against me.
“Why*pn did you bring me out from the womb? Would*ld that I had died before any eye had seen me
and*ln were as though I had not been, carried*ld from the womb to the grave.
Are*ln not my days few? Then*ld cease, and leave me alone, that I may find a little cheer
before*ln I go— and I shall not return— to*ld the land of darkness and deep shadow,
the*ln land of gloom like thick darkness, like*ld deep shadow without any order, where*ld light is as thick darkness.”
